justification: The package contains only 1 class and 56 LOC, which is small and not indicative of an excessively large component. Class-level metrics (nof=3, nom=6, wmc=7) show modest complexity, and fanin/fanout are 0. Package coupling metrics (Ce=0, Ca=0) show no heavy dependency concentration. There is no evidence of excessive lines of code or a large number of classes that would justify labeling this package as a God Component.

Although the package contains 32 classes and 2,709 LOC, the work is distributed among many small, focused classes (many under ~130 LOC) implementing individual file filters. Coupling is low (Ce=5, Ca=3, fanin/fanout mostly 0) and classes exhibit targeted responsibilities (low/narrow nc, modest WMC for most). There is a single larger utility class (FileFilterUtils: 469 LOC, 43 methods) but it appears to be an aggregator/helper rather than evidence the entire package centralizes unrelated functionality. Overall the package structure and metrics indicate cohesion and modularity rather than an excessively large God Component.

The package contains 9,478 LOC across 40 classes with a highly skewed distribution: IOUtils (2,487 LOC, 172 methods, WMC 275) and FileUtils (2,371 LOC, 159 methods, WMC 244) alone account for roughly half of the package size. Several other large classes (FilenameUtils 928 LOC, FileSystem 433 LOC, EndianUtils 355 LOC, DirectoryWalker 261 LOC) further concentrate functionality. The very high LOC, large numbers of methods and high complexity (WMC) in a few classes indicate excessive responsibilities concentrated in single components, supporting the detection of a God Component at the package level.

The package contains 17 classes and 1,633 LOC with a strong concentration of size and complexity in a few classes: AbstractOrigin (614 LOC, wmc 21), AbstractStreamBuilder (288 LOC, wmc 26) and AbstractOriginSupplier (283 LOC, wmc 34) — these three account for ~72% of the package LOC. AbstractOrigin also defines many nested origin types within a single file, indicating multiple responsibilities collocated. The high LOC and weighted methods per class values combined with multiple cohesive responsibilities suggest the package is excessively large and acting as a God Component.

The package contains 34 classes and 2,198 LOC with several very large, highly complex classes concentrated in it (notably IOStream: 394 LOC, 42 methods, WMC 44; Uncheck: 342 LOC, 22 methods, WMC 22; Erase: 150 LOC; IOFunction: 123 LOC; IOConsumer: 116 LOC). These classes centralize many methods and high cyclomatic complexity values, indicating concentrated responsibilities and size within the package. The combination of moderate-to-high class count plus multiple large, complex classes supports identifying this package as a God Component.

The package contains 7 classes and a total of 579 LOC, which is moderate in size and not excessive for a small utility package. Although ValidatingObjectInputStream is relatively large (278 LOC, nom=17, wmc=19) and could be a candidate for class-level refactoring, the remainder of the classes are small (LOC 11–123, most under ~25 LOC). The class count (7) is low and the package LOC is not overwhelmingly large, so the package as a whole does not qualify as a "God Component."

The package contains only one class (num_classes = 1) and total LOC = 225, which is not excessively large in the provided context. The single class FileTimes has 225 LOC, 24 methods and WMC = 26 (moderate complexity) but no fan-in/fan-out or external dependencies. LCOM ≈ 0.71 indicates reasonable cohesion. There is no evidence of an excessively large number of classes or an unusually large component size that would justify labeling this package as a God Component.

The package contains 29 classes and 3,723 LOC, indicating a large component. Code is heavily concentrated in a few very large classes: PathUtils alone is 1,516 LOC with 109 methods and WMC 158 (≈40.7% of package LOC), FilesUncheck is 563 LOC, Counters is 309 LOC, CountingPathVisitor is 226 LOC and AccumulatorPathVisitor 178 LOC. Several classes contain many nested/inner types (e.g., Counters, PathUtils), and large method counts/complexities (nom/WMC) further concentrate responsibility. This size and concentration of functionality justify identifying the package as a God Component.

The package contains a very large number of classes (52) and a high total size (≈4700 LOC), indicating an excessive component size. Several classes are individually large and complex (examples: AbstractByteArrayOutputStream loc=322 wmc=40, LockableFileWriter loc=327 wmc=28, DeferredFileOutputStream loc=322 wmc=25, WriterOutputStream loc=278 wmc=26, ProxyWriter loc=194, XmlStreamWriter loc=193), showing concentrated complexity and multiple responsibilities. The presence of many builder/nested types and many medium-to-large utility classes in the same package suggests the package is doing too much and would benefit from decomposition. These elements support detecting a God Component smell for org.apache.commons.io.output.

The package contains 7 classes and 947 LOC, which is moderate for a focused monitoring package and not excessive in number of classes. The size is concentrated in two classes (FileAlterationObserver: 375 LOC, WMC 45, 29 methods; FileEntry: 212 LOC) while the other classes are small (LOC 47–150). There are no incoming dependencies (Ca = 0) and the package has limited external coupling (Ce = 6). Although FileAlterationObserver shows high complexity and could be a candidate for class-level refactoring (god class), the package as a whole does not present an excessive size in LOC or class count to qualify as a God Component.

The package contains only 3 classes and a total of 343 LOC, which is modest in size for a package. Although CircularByteBuffer is the largest class (196 LOC, WMC 34, 13 methods) and accounts for ~57% of the package LOC, the package as a whole is not excessively large in terms of number of classes or total LOC. Coupling is low (Ce=1, Ca=0) and the other classes are small (98 LOC and 49 LOC). Given the provided data and without broader project context, this package does not meet the contextual criteria for a God Component.

The package contains only 4 classes and 458 LOC in total, which is not excessively large in context. The largest class (ByteArraySeekableByteChannel) is 202 LOC with 18 methods and WMC 33 — sizeable but not overwhelmingly dominant relative to the package. Other classes are 118, 99, and 39 LOC. Coupling indicators are low (Ca=0, Ce=2) and there is no indication of extreme concentration of functionality or unusually high class count. Based on these metrics, the component does not exhibit the excessive size characterizing a God Component.

The package org.apache.commons.io.input is excessively large: 101 classes and 10,353 LOC. The package contains many very large classes (examples: Tailer 683 LOC, XmlStreamReader 541 LOC, ReadAheadInputStream 401 LOC, ReversedLinesFileReader 375 LOC, BoundedInputStream 327 LOC, UnsynchronizedBufferedReader 327 LOC, ProxyInputStream 249 LOC, CharSequenceInputStream 237 LOC, NullInputStream 238 LOC), plus numerous inner/builder classes, indicating concentrated and substantial implementation. The afferent/efferent coupling (Ca=5, Ce=8) suggests this size is due to internal volume rather than external distribution. These elements collectively support detecting a God Component in this package.

The package contains 10 classes and 490 LOC (avg ~49 LOC/class), which is moderate rather than excessive. No single class dominates the LOC (largest is 77 LOC). Class-level complexity metrics (wmc generally 2–8, nom small) and cohesion (lcom values low) are low, and fanin/fanout are zero for listed classes. Afferent/efferent couplings (Ca=1, Ce=2) are minimal. Based on these metrics and the lack of a very large or highly complex class, there is insufficient evidence to classify this package as a God Component.

The package contains only 2 classes and 48 LOC in total (classes: CharsetEncoders 29 LOC, CharsetDecoders 19 LOC). Method counts are small (nom 3 and 2) and WMCs are low (3 and 2). Fan-in/fan-out are 0 and there are no package-level dependencies indicating centralization. Given the very small size and low complexity, this package is not excessively large and does not qualify as a God Component.
